abstracts.cdata!:
The Agricultural Rehabilitation
            Project's outcome is rated as satisfactory,
            institutional development impact as modest, sustainability
            as likely, borrower performance as satisfactory, and Bank
            performance as satisfactory. OED assessment focused
            particularly on one sub-component, the Integrated Pest
            Management sub-component. It is the first time that OED has
            looked at impact from this new and expanding area of Bank
            rural lending. Efficiency and fiscal sustainability are
            questionable in this component. The project offers five main
            lessons: 1) Developing a poverty-related logical framework
            helps to clarify the poverty rationale. 2) Mechanisms to
            ensure sustainability become more a function of reforms that
            deliver self-sustaining institutions and cost recovery at
            the local level than public expenditure commitment from the
            center. 3) This project raises efficiency and sustainability
            questions about the use of separate PCUs. 4) Key elements in
            scaling up extension include maximizing farmer-to-farmer
            diffusion, enhancing the capacity of farmers to develop
            their own solutions, cost recovery or privatization,
            minimizing the cost of trainers through the use of
            farmer-trainers, and low-cost mass media approach. 5)
            Projects complex design could benefit from the Computer
            Project Management systems to track and manage expenditure.

1980469.trustfund:
TF026400-FRENCH AGRI. & FORESTRY
            CONSULTANT TF,TF020761-AUSTRALIAN CONSULTANTS TRUST
            FUND (USD),TF026485-AUDIT OF VIET NAM BANK FOR AGRICULTURE

abstracts.cdata!:
While the outcome of the project is
            satisfactory, with a likely sustainability, the
            institutional development impact fell short of expectations,
            partly due to the postponement of the study for
            restructuring the Ministry of Agriculture and Rural
            Development (MARD), where strengthening its policy planning
            capacity should have been considered a matter of urgency.
            Key lessons reinforce the notion that sound sector planning
            should precede rural development projects, particularly in
            transition countries, to achieve the expected agricultural
            management results. Furthermore, provision should be made to
            ensure continuity of supportive services following project
            completion, for a potential replication to non-project
            areas. Small-holder credit operations require independent,
            and viable financial institutions, with qualified
            experienced staff, and management to supervise, focusing on
            timely repayments. Regarding administrative aspects, where
            diverse project activities exist, it is worth considering
            separate project coordination units for each component, in
            addition to Bank staff continuity, to ensure close, and
            flexible supervision for successful implementation. Finally,
            government ownership is paramount in providing counterpart
            funds for the sustenance of project activities, in a timely fashion.

18152559.admreg: East Asia and Pacific,East Asia and Pacific
18152559.theme: Rural services and infrastructure,Rural markets,Other financial and private sector development,Micro, Small and Medium Enterprise support
18152559.trustfund:
TF026485-AUDIT OF VIET NAM BANK FOR AGRICULTURE,TF026400-FRENCH AGRI. & FORESTRY
            CONSULTANT TF,TF020761-AUSTRALIAN CONSULTANTS TRUST
            FUND (USD)
18152559.majtheme: Rural development,Financial and private sector development

abstracts.cdata!:
The objectives of the project are to
            support Government efforts to increase rural incomes and to
            assist Viet Nam's transition to a market economy
            through assistance to key agriculture institutions serving
            the newly emerged smallholder sector and to rubber
            production. It will be the first project in the sector since
            1978 and will: 1) help rehabilitate agricultural support
            services by providing assistance to decentralize extension
            in 23 provinces, to improve plant protection services
            including integrated pest management, and to strengthen
            research in three key institutes; 2) provide supervised
            credit to about 50,000 private smallholder farm households
            in 10 provinces to purchase fertilizer, improved seeds and
            other inputs, and for on-farm development works; 3)
            rehabilitate about 160,000 ha of already established rubber
            of high potential productivity, provide additional
            processing capacity and upgrade the quality of rubber being
            produced through construction of 5 new latex processing
            facilities and rehabilitation of 4 old latex facilities; and
            4) provide training, and technical assistance for policy
            analysis and preparation of follow-up projects to give more
            specialized assistance to the sector.
